reviewText:
Disciples II is a turn-based strategy/RPG. Players send parties of fantasy heroes around the overworld to kill monsters, get loot, and conquer enemy towns. As you play through the campaign, you can continue to level up one specific hero, and I found myself having this one hero single-handedly slaughtering armies. It's tough to level up other parties since there aren't many weak enemies. The game's a little slow-paced, but building up your party and winning with it is fun. It definitely has some depth. If you like it, it can keep you busy for a long time.

The tutorial was not good, but the game is ultimately not that tough to figure out.

The game's art is very well-done for being entirely 2D. The music works. The plot is boring, at least for the human campaign (haven't made it to the others yet). A warning: it doesn't play well with modern systems, but I got it to work eventually.

For strategy fans (maybe RPG fans too), I think the game's worth buying.

reviewText:
This game is kind of a mixed bag.

On one hand, I really like the unit designs and atmosphere of the game.

On the other, the actual gameplay is pretty terrible.

The problem with the game is that it advertises itself as a strategy game when the strategy is really to have your one leader and one band of guys roam the map fighting things...in turn based fashion.  To top this all off, only one faction (2 if you count the elves) get healers, so the end result is moving your stack of dwarves/demons/undead out of the base, blowing up some random crap, and going back to base to heal.  If you are playing with harder AI you will receive the privilege of getting pummeled with map spells which the AI can drop all day every day but you are limited by resources.  You take your one hero through each level and only the hero, meaning the first part of every level is releveling up the support peons.

Game design suffers too, with such gems as:
-units who can stunlock the entire enemy party!
-the final boss who can stunlock your entire team AND deal damage while doing it!
-front-line units who are immune to weapons, with the drawback, that, um....
-each faction does only one type of elemental damage (save the dwarves) meaning that if you ever run into say, a dragon while playing as the devils, you're totally screwed.

I want to like this game, but the gameplay just doesn't justify it.

reviewText:
Playing Disciples II is the Turn-Based Strategy equivalent of sitting at home buzzsawing through a huge bag of greasy, salty potato chips. I know for a fact that there are way better things I could be doing.  I also know that what I'm eating has next to no meaningfull nutritional content. They don't even taste especially good, and I'm getting bored and frustrated and only eating out of habit.  So why the hell am I still eating?!

Well, the game does look pretty, in that early-Rennaissance-variant Grimdark(TM) way. It also offers reasonably steady advancement in power, and a few head-scratching tactical challenges.

Mostly, though, it comes down to grinding, hoarding and (save) scumming. Grinding: learn to recognize the fights your troops can survive and still gain meaningful XP from, keep hitting as fast as you safely can till your dudes gain a few levels and a commensurate capacity to curb-stomp anything other than the final battle (troop upgrade levels determine any fight that hasn't been pre-determined by magic or thief spam: a difference of one level guarantees the higher-tier army will win, two or more guarantees a massacre.)  Hoarding: get mines and mana nodes. Money is necessary for Grinding, since the buildings needed to upgrade your troops get hella expensive at tiers 4 and 5, while mana powers the spells that tilt combats. Use as little mana and money as needed to keep your troops alive and upgrading, then when the map's big bad comes into view burn it to guarantee a win. Cast every spell you can, twice if you can, send mobs of Thieves to soften up fortified armies, send disposable heroes leading quick-firing ranged units, you get the idea. Scumming occurs when those first two don't work, or are derailed by unforseen circumstances, which becomes more common as you climb the difficulty levels. The couple of different auto-save functions make this slightly less irritating.

The end result is a game where fights can largely be predicted in advance (no tactical genius can offset spell bombardment or superior forces), and strategy between fights is largely a matter of trial and error. You can let it eat up a ton of time, or you could go play something more interesting.

(Yes, I know this review sounds like a three-hundred-pound couch potato telling his kids to exercise. Remember, folks: hypocrisy is the debt vice pays to virtue.)

Disciples II: Gallean's Return is a compilation edition that includes the base game, Disciples II: Dark Prophecy, plus the two standalone expansions Disciples II: Guardians of the Light and Disciples II: Servants of the Dark.
Disciples II: Guardians of the Light is a stand-alone expansion that lets you dive into the fantastical world of Disciples II as either the Empire or the Mountain Clans.

The Empire is decaying from within as self-proclaimed rulers struggle for control of the now vacant throne while a cruel Inquisition sweeps across the human lands, causing rebellion and misery. Meanwhile the Clans, recovering from their near-destruction, begin to reunite their tribes. They have received divine instructions and now seek to uncover an ancient ritual that will let them communicate with their god, Wotan.

Disciples II: Servants of the Dark is a stand-alone expansion that brings you into the never-ending quest for supremacy as either the Undead Hordes or the Legions of the Damned.

On the dark side, the Legions of the Damned enact a plan to spread Bethrezen’s plague across Nevendaar. They sense the threat brought about by the rebirth of the Elven god and will stop at nothing to steal this power for their own purposes. reviewText:
Although a lot of these reviews claim this game is broken and unplayable on Win7, that isn't the case, as a few minor tweaks (compatibility, run as admin., etc.) will make the game run fine. However, the game is by far one of the most unbalanced and least enjoyable games I have ever played.
Anyone who has ever played the Might and Magic series will certainly be familiar with a high level of difficulty, but in that series a thorough grasp of the game mechanics combined with  a few false starts as you acquaint yourself with the lay of land will ultimately allow you to complete the missions. To take another example, the excellent Age of Wonders series (my personal benchmark for strategy/rpg excellence) is often said to be punishing, but the fact is once you learn all the game's tools, it's a rich and highly rewarding experience and there's no reason why you can't complete missions in fine fashion.
Disciples 2, on the other hand, is simply an exercise in masochism. Yes, the missions can be completed, but not without an excessive and highly frustrating amount of bloodletting, dying, reviving, etc., as from the start you will find that EVERY enemy on the map is stronger than you. Nor does it get better, as your character's progression -- should you be fortunate enough to carry one from one mission to the next -- is minimal at best and hardly matters compared to the strength of the monsters. Buffers offer only the most marginal of enhancements to your troops' stats, costly spells bestow laughable gains (10 fire damage to 300 HP monsters, oh boy), and hard-won battles are rewarded by the most modest and least consequential of loot drops.
It's only been from sheer stubbornness that I've persisted to the second mission (halfway through and looking bleak, overpowered beasts everywhere), but frankly, aside from the so-so graphics and music, this game offers precious little in the way of enjoyment.

reviewText:
Disciples II is strongly reminiscent of Heroes of Might and Magic III mixed with the Ogre Battle series of games, and the mix is succesfully engaging

Those familiar with HoMMIII should feel comfortable with the turn based play, isometric map, resources, town building and creature tiers. The primary difference is in the combat.

As in Ogre Battle, combat takes place between squads that meet up on the map. Rather than stacks of creatures, each member of a squad is a single creature with a health bar. A number of rules dictate the squad composition: A squad has a limited number of slots, a large creatures may take up multiple slots, some units can only attack from the front row, others from both. To this end it's greatly engaging experimenting with squad composition and placement, building countersquads, attrition squads, and so on. I recommend this to fans of either of the two games it resembles, or simply fantasy TBS's in general

reviewText:
This was one of my absolute favourites as a baby gamer. What caused me to responde so much about this game is its atmosphere: its high fantasy, decadent design, the beautiful beautiful isometric landscapes, the sombre, solemn music, the epic quality of the story.
I recall the sheer pleasure in immersing myself in this dark world where there are no good sides and everything is permeated by this sort of gritty grandeur.

Gameplay-wise, it is very similar to the Heroes of Might and Magic titles, with a decisively steeper difficulty curve. Resource management is particularly tricky in this one, especially once you get to play the biggest maps. The different factions are all very well characterised not only in terms of design and contextualization, but also in gameplay. Every single one of them plays different strategies best: the Legion of the Damned has excellent nukers and favours brief fights, the Undead Hordes deploys excellent crowd control, the Empire thrives in longer fights combining sustain and utility, etc.
Also their power spikes - provided by mainly by unlocking units and spells - happen at different times for each faction, providing added layer of complexity to the gameplay. To know when and why invest to accelerate towards said power spikes is absolutely key if you want to play the highest difficulty level - definitely the most rewarding.

Added perk: an excellent scenario editor. I had the time of my life crafting from scratch epic campaigns for my brother and friends using its gorgeous graphics and the dumb-proof interface. A wonderful experience.

The rough jest of getting it to work is....
Set compatibility to Win XP service pack 2 for both the game and the configuration tool (you'll have to go to the actual .exe files in your steam directory).
Disable the intro video from the configuration screen
Also enable Direct3D, Stretch to Full Screen, and Compatibility Mode from the configuration screen
Disable the Steam overlay (right click the game title from your list, hit properties, and uncheck the box that allows that annoying shift-tab menu that pops up everytime you play a game)

Last thing I did was...
Open up control panel
Click on system
Click on advanced system settings
Click Environment Variables
Click on path, then click edit (path is likely already highlighted, so you might just have to click edit only)
Add (remove the quotations) ;%PROGRAMFILES(X86)%\Steam" to the end of whatever is there
